docs.lead_paragraph: Farms in upstate New York and elsewhere are using automatic milkers that scan and map the underbellies of cows, extract the milk, and monitor its quality, without the use of human hands.

headline.main: With Farm Robotics, the Cows Decide When It’s Milking Time
headline.print_headline: With Farm Robotics, the Cows Decide When It’s Milking Time

docs.abstract: Dairy operations across New York State are turning to robotic milkers, which feed and milk cows without the help of farmhands; robots allow for variety of improvements, including providing cows with individualized service and monitoring amount and quality of milk produced; trend is driven primarily by need for cutting labor costs and difficulties in procuring dependable workers.
docs.snippet: Farms in upstate New York and elsewhere are using automatic milkers that scan and map the underbellies of cows, extract the milk, and monitor its quality, without the use of human hands.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act may well be on track to meeting its primary goal, but reining in health care spending still appears well beyond the grasp of the law.

headline.main: Acceleration Is Forecast for Spending on Health
headline.print_headline: Acceleration Is Forecast for Spending on Health

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column; Affordable Care Act may well be on track to meeting its primary goal of providing coverage for most uninsured Americans, but reining in health care spending still appears well beyond the grasp of the law.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act may well be on track to meeting its primary goal, but reining in health care spending still appears well beyond the grasp of the law.

headline.main: What Business Spends to Open Washington's Doors

docs.abstract: The Chamber of Commerce spent $19 million on lobbying in just the first three months of 2014.
docs.snippet: The Chamber of Commerce spent $19 million on lobbying in just the first three months of 2014.

docs.lead_paragraph: The candidate in North Carolina's Republican Senate primary with backing from the party's Washington establishment came under little direct criticism Tuesday night as his top rivals had their first real chance to challenge him face to face.

headline.main: Republicans in NC's Senate Race Trade Few Hits
headline.print_headline: Republicans in NC's Senate Race Trade Few Hits

docs.snippet: The candidate in North Carolina's Republican Senate primary with backing from the party's Washington establishment came under little direct criticism Tuesday night as his top rivals had their first real chance to challenge him face to face.

headline.main: Bain Goes Off Script for Its Latest Deal

docs.abstract: With Viewpoint Construction Software, Bain Capital is demonstrating its willingness to make investments that are smaller than the leveraged buyouts for which it is better known.
docs.snippet: With Viewpoint Construction Software, Bain Capital is demonstrating its willingness to make investments that are smaller than the leveraged buyouts for which it is better known.

docs.lead_paragraph: Carmen Collado has laundered hospital linen in Madrid for 11 years. Now, almost half her colleagues have been fired and the 61-year-old grandmother is cleaning the same bed sheets, nurses' scrubs and towels as before for half the pay.

headline.main: Wage Cuts Make Spain's Recovery a Long, Painful Path
headline.print_headline: Wage Cuts Make Spain's Recovery a Long, Painful Path

docs.snippet: Carmen Collado has laundered hospital linen in Madrid for 11 years. Now, almost half her colleagues have been fired and the 61-year-old grandmother is cleaning the same bed sheets, nurses' scrubs and towels as before for half the pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a driver hit a 10-year-old boy, a crowd beat him until he was unconscious, stopping only when a retired nurse intervened. Five young men face charges in the case.

headline.main: A Driver’s Bloody Run-In With an Angry Detroit
headline.print_headline: A Driver’s Bloody Run-In With an Angry Detroit

docs.abstract: Severe beating of white driver Steve Utash by African-American crowd in Detroit after he accidentally struck a 10-year-old boy highlights broader, more complicated problem of crime and violence in largely segregated metropolitan area; five young men face charges in beating Utash unconscious; as church and civic leaders condemn attack and some in neighborhood step forward to identify those involved, Detroit begins searching its soul to repair damage.
docs.snippet: After a driver hit a 10-year-old boy, a crowd beat him until he was unconscious, stopping only when a retired nurse intervened. Five young men face charges in the case.

docs.lead_paragraph: A month after the lightning annexation of Crimea, residents find themselves in a state of confusion, with few institutions functioning normally, including banks, courts and foreign businesses.

headline.main: Under Russia, Life in Crimea Grows Chaotic
headline.print_headline: Under Russia, Life in Crimea Grows Chaotic

docs.abstract: Residents of Crimea find themselves in a state of confusion one month after lightning annexation by Russia, with few institutions functioning normally, including banks, courts and foreign businesses; chaotic transition comes amid evolving tensions in nearby eastern Ukraine, where possible outcomes include Crimea-annexation replay.
docs.snippet: A month after the lightning annexation of Crimea, residents find themselves in a state of confusion, with few institutions functioning normally, including banks, courts and foreign businesses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans who have chosen to be uninsured cited cost, frustration and ideology as some of the reasons they sat out the first open enrollment period of the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Looking at Costs and Risks, Many Skip Health Insurance
headline.print_headline: Looking at Costs and Risks, Many Skip Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Many Americans are deciding to forgo health insurance, despite income tax penalty, citing costs, frustration with the process and ideology among reasons; those who sat out the first enrollment period of the Affordable Care Act represent next challenge for Obama administration as it struggles to reduce ranks of uninsured and broaden support for president's signature health care law.
docs.snippet: Americans who have chosen to be uninsured cited cost, frustration and ideology as some of the reasons they sat out the first open enrollment period of the Affordable Care Act.
